document.title: Building a Modern Portfolio with Next.js
document.description: A deep dive into creating a modern developer portfolio using Next.js, Tailwind CSS, and Framer Motion.

body.raw:
# Building a Modern Portfolio with Next.js Creating a modern developer portfolio is more than just showcasing your work—it's about crafting an experience that reflects your skills and personality. In this post, I'll share my journey of building this portfolio website using Next.js 13, Tailwind CSS, and Framer Motion. ## The Tech Stack I chose a modern tech stack that prioritizes both developer experience and performance: - **Next.js 13** - For server-side rendering and optimal performance - **Tailwind CSS** - For rapid, utility-first styling - **Framer Motion** - For smooth, engaging animations - **Contentlayer** - For type-safe content management ## Key Features ### 1. Dark Mode by Default The dark theme isn't just an aesthetic choice—it's designed to be easy on the eyes while maintaining excellent contrast and readability. Using CSS variables allows for seamless theme customization: ```css :root { --background: 240 10% 3.9%; --foreground: 0 0% 98%; /* ... other variables */ } ``` ### 2. Responsive Design The portfolio is built with a mobile-first approach, ensuring a great experience across all devices. Using Tailwind's responsive modifiers makes this straightforward: ```jsx
{/* Content */}
``` ### 3. Smooth Animations Framer Motion adds life to the interface with subtle, purposeful animations: ```jsx {/* Content */} ``` ## Performance Considerations Performance was a key focus throughout development. Some strategies I employed: 1. Image optimization with Next.js Image component 2. Code splitting and lazy loading 3. Static site generation for blog posts 4. Minimal JavaScript bundle size ## Conclusion Building this portfolio has been an exciting journey of balancing aesthetics with performance. The combination of Next.js, Tailwind CSS, and Framer Motion proved to be powerful for creating a modern, performant website. Stay tuned for more posts about web development, design, and technology!

document.title: Hello World
document.description: Welcome to my blog! This is my first post.

body.raw:
# Welcome to my blog!

This is my first blog post. I'll be writing about my experiences as a developer, sharing tutorials, and discussing interesting tech topics.

## What to expect

- Technical tutorials
- Project updates
- Thoughts on software development
- Tips and tricks

Stay tuned for more content!

document.title: Smash Minecraft Skins
document.description: A mod for downloading and using your own Minecraft skin to use in-game. Just enter in your username! Includes a custom menu to select a skin, the ability to download a skin from a minecraft username, and on-the-fly file conversion and UI portrait rendering. All written in Rust and running on the Switch itself.
document.stats: over 1.5 Million views on twitter alone

body.raw:
# Smash Minecraft Skins

A mod that brings Minecraft skins to Super Smash Bros Ultimate...

document.title: RustConf 2020 Talk
document.description: The macro system in Rust is still arguably in its infancy. While a lot of the implementation has already been done, plenty of projects don't properly take advantage of macros due to the limited resources on what macro programming should look like. This talk is aimed at introducing those interested in using macros in existing or future projects to macro idioms often needed in order to write clean and maintainable macro code.

body.raw:
# RustConf 2020 Talk: Macros for a More Productive Rust

A comprehensive talk about writing clean and maintainable macro code...
